greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Number of ways to write the n-th prime as a sum of distinct primes.
link: David A. Corneth, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10000 (first 1201 terms from Seth Troisi)
example: With the 10th prime 29, for instance, we have a(10)=7 distinct-prime partitions, viz. 29 = 2 + 3 + 7 + 17 = 2 + 3 + 5 + 19 = 2 + 3 + 11 + 13 = 3 + 7 + 19 = 5 + 7 + 17 = 5 + 11 + 13.
mathematica: nn = PrimePi[300]; t = CoefficientList[Series[Product[(1 + x^Prime[k]), {k, nn}], {x, 0, Prime[nn]}], x]; t[[1 + Prime[Range[nn]]]] (* _T. D. Noe_, Nov 13 2013 *)
results.author: _Lekraj Beedassy_, May 07 2002
